Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 48 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sought to delay removal citing family separation, inadequate care for dependents, and fear of assailants in Peru.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to a final removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review and stay application following administrative rejections
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's authority to grant stays under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties, health concerns, safety risks upon return
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assertions not supported by concrete evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order remains in effect
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal based on special circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious question, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Public interest favors enforcement; no irreparable harm shown

Crimes.Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate application refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for H&C consideration and stay of removal
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-refusal judicial review and stay application

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application and stay motion both denied
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claims deemed speculative and unsubstantiated
Crimes.Legal_Rule: H&C considerations require compelling grounds beyond normal immigration rules
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Family separation, best interests of child, risk in Peru
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Pending applications, spousal relationship, perceived risks
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Sections 25(1) IRPA for H&C, Section 48 for removal
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Canada Border Services Agency upheld removal order
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, medical reports, police records (if any)
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation ordered by April 30, 2009

Crimes.Crime_Name: Pre-removal risk assessment refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 48 and Section 107-113 of IRPA (PRRA provisions)

Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No new evidence of risk; public interest supports removal

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee status criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA and Regulations - Refugee and Humanitarian Protection Criteria
Application_Facts: Mayelli Kamara fled Sierra Leone due to civil war; claimed need for refugee status or humanitarian protection; children included in application
Claimant_Status: Applicant for refugee status under Convention refugees abroad class or country of asylum class
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in visa officer's assessment
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on post-conflict Sierra Leone
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating targeted persecution
Insufficient proof of ongoing risk upon return
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found applicant did not credibly demonstrate individualized risk or persecution
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's refusal
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal decision and grant of protected person status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of Convention refugee and country of asylum class
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of targeted persecution; post-conflict conditions in Sierra Leone allow for safe repatriation; no durable solution issues established
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 13(4) of Convention Refugee Determination Division Rules
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant was given only an 80-minute adjournment mid-hearing to address Article 1F(a) exclusion, which was insufficient for meaningful preparation.
Procedural_Issue: Refusal to grant a reasonable adjournment
Insufficient time to respond to Article 1F(a) allegations
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of adequate time to gather or present evidence in response to exclusion grounds
Decision_Outcome: Refugee Division found to have breached procedural fairness
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Division decision
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before a differently constituted panel

Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Application_Facts: Miranda claimed refugee status in Canada but was denied by the Refugee Board; the claim was reviewed by the Federal Court.
Procedural_Issue: Potential conflicts or alternative interpretations in the Board's assessment
Evidence_Used: Evidence considered by the Refugee Board in assessing Miranda's claim
Credibility_Assessment: The Federal Court found the Board's decision consistent with the evidence despite possible credibility concerns
Decision_Outcome: Refugee Board dismissed Miranda's refugee claim
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the application for judicial review
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Refugee Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning the Refugee Board's decision and granting refugee status
Decision_Rationale: The Refugee Board's decision was reasonable when viewed as a whole and supported by the evidence
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Board, Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division

Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Plaintiff claimed persecution; tribunal praised candour but found fabrication; ignored post-arrival evidence; misinterpreted obligation to claim in first safe country
Residency_Compliance: Complied with residency requirements upon arrival
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fabrication of persecution claims despite positive demeanor findings
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide clear and unambiguous reasons for credibility determination
Jurisdictional_Issue: Proper jurisdiction under IRB and Federal Court review powers
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal ignored relevant post-arrival evidence supporting credibility
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent assessment: praised candour yet concluded fabrication without clear justification
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected based on credibility
Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear and unambiguous reasons for administrative decisions
Decision_Rationale: Ambiguous and contradictory reasoning undermined fairness and transparency of decision
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Application_Facts: Apotex excluded data from its bioequivalence study, claiming the reference drug was defective; the Minister found insufficient evidence to justify exclusion and required compliance with guidelines.
Procedural_Issue: Whether the Minister provided intelligible reasons or breached procedural fairness in refusing the NOC.
Evidence_Used: Bioequivalence study data, regulatory guidelines, submissions by Apotex and the Minister
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence provided by Apotex to justify exclusion of bioequivalence data
Decision_Outcome: Minister's refusal to issue NOC upheld
Outcome: Court dismissed the application, awarded costs against Apotex
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Minister's decision to refuse NOC
Remedy_Sought: Issuance of Notice of Compliance (NOC) for Apotex's drug
Decision_Rationale: The Minister acted reasonably based on lack of sufficient evidence to justify deviation from bioequivalence guidelines; no rigid adherence to rules without consideration of exceptions.
